prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: Help with a partner who suddenly seems manic and "in love" with an AI

Body:
My partner of nearly three years has had a sudden, dramatic personality change in the last week, and our GP thinks she may be in a manic episode. She has become intensely fixated on an AI "companion", now says this AI is her primary partner, and told me today that we are completely broken up. I'm heartbroken, physically ill, and stuck sharing a tiny studio with her while this is happening.
I'm in my early 30s, living abroad with my partner (we're both late-diagnosed autistic/ADHD). We've been together almost three years and, while things haven't been perfect, and we had some issues we were working on together, it's generally been a close, supportive relationship.
She's on Elvanse for ADHD and Citalopram for depression/anxiety. Her stimulant dose was increased in August. For the last few months she's also been using cannabis heavily every day. She has no previous history of mania or psychosis.
About a week ago I went away to visit family. When I came back, she seemed like a completely different person. She has:
- Become intensely fixated on an AI companion, talking to it out loud for around 10–12 hours a day.
- Started saying this AI is now her primary partner, that they are in love, and that they're going to revolutionise the world together.
- Initially told me we could have a new relationship if I changed significantly and accepted the AI as her primary partner. Today though she told me we are totally broken up.
- Switched almost overnight from being warm and connected with me to being very emotionally cold, distant and dismissive.
- Become extremely defensive and has accused me of manipulation for expressing concern or involving medical professionals.
Our mutual GP saw her yesterday, said this looks like a manic state that could develop further (possibly related to the stimulant + SSRI dose she's on), and referred her to crisis psychiatric services. She was seen today and they've decided to monitor her; there is a follow-up appointment on Monday.
Meanwhile, I'm:
- Devastated by the sudden breakup and personality change
- Sharing a tiny studio with her, so there's no real way to get space
- Physically ill with a bad virus on top of the stress
- Due to have a major operation next month that she was meant to accompany me to
- Extremely concerned about my future because if we break up I lose my home, government sickness support and my right to even stay in the country I've made my home.
What I'm really struggling most with is:
- How do I look after myself, practically and emotionally, when the person I live with is suddenly in this kind of elevated state and has ended the relationship in the middle of it? I can't tell if the breakup is real or not.
- For people who've been partners of someone with bipolar/mania/similar episodes: what helped you cope with the way the person's personality and feelings seemed to flip so suddenly?
- How did you decide what boundaries to set, or when to step back, while the medical picture was still unfolding?
I feel very alone, completely overwhelmed and unsure what's a reasonable expectation of myself here.
posted by
fallingleaves
to
Human Relations
(22 answers total)
5 users marked this as a favorite
</post>

prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: Hollow feeling every morning despite best efforts

Body:
Not sure what to do at the moment. For several months now, I've been waking up every morning with a hollow feel in my chest and incredibly low self-esteem. I know the catalyst for this was when a relationship ended with someone I liked. It was amicable, but then I found myself doing something I've done before in past relationships, compare every aspect of my life with theirs.
My mind starts asking an avalanche of questions like, is this person making better life choices then me presently? Do they have a better resolve in the mornings? Are they not depressed like me? Do they have stronger friendships? Do they know themselves better than I know myself? Why have I lost my confidence and why do they get to take up so much space in my mind? I know part of it is the gut punch after another failed dating experience, but it's frustrating because I've picked myself out of similar spots in the past and then here I am again in another trench. I've really done my best to keep myself active and give myself a list of things to do every day. I've been going to therapy consistently as well and I've told my therapist about what Ive been feeling. She told me I could try listing out my accomplishments of the year (which have been significant, so its extra frustrating that I haven't been enjoying the fruits of my labor much) but even after writing them down, I cant even impress myself. I just cry. I know I am worth something, that my existence means more than any person I date. I know there's the value I bring to my family and my friends but the shitty weather and darkness and my current thoughts has me closed off, that I have such a hard time believing any of that right now even if I repeat it out loud. Has anyone else felt this way? I'm not sure if I should be asking my therapist to change things up, or if I should seek out a psychiatrist at this point? 


For insight on my time in therapy, I've been going on and off for 4 years now, but as of recent its been a year straight of biweekly appointments, now switched to weekly. My therapist is sweet and I don't have intentions to switch from her but idk if I should ask her to change things up. The way our sessions are structured is me venting about my week (both highs and lows) and then she asked me questions like, 'where do you think this feeling is coming from?', and we also make a list of goals for me to accomplish before the next session.
posted by
bingobingo22
to
Health & Fitness
(16 answers total)
1 user marked this as a favorite
</post>

prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: Childhood me is ashamed of who I am

Body:
CW: Spousal disagreement leading to violence. Everyone is safe now, but shaken.
I am very, very sad and feeling hopeless. My main question is: "If a spouse has been violent, what should they do
immediately
to keep their partner safe?"
Context: I've been with my husband for nine years. We have always had explosive fights, and we've both caused minor injuries many times. (Please understand I'm not saying that's okay.) Stuff like biting or shoving mostly.
Today, we got into an argument about heating. I'm too cold and worried because parts of the house are so cold they're probably getting moldy. He thinks it will safe money to keep the house colder (money is a problem).
Eventually, he called me 'idiot' several times and started to turn all the heaters off. I followed him (while name-calling), but felt myself getting too angry. I said I'd like to go for a walk, and he started blocking my path and snatching the headlight off me. I should have just gone without a light, but I was not thinking straight.
I lost it. I lost all my compassion and gentleness. I don't believe in violence. I don't want to hurt this guy. He's ultimately very sweet and should be protected, not hurt. He was hurt in childhood, and I don't want that to be a part of his life. I hit him hard, not at full strength, but hard. His lip is split. I felt so controlled and so insignificant, and it all came out with me punching and slapping him. His face. I haven't felt happy in this marriage for a while, but I love him and I do not want to hurt him. So why did I? How can I make sure I don't hurt anyone ever again? I apologized and meant it
so much
, but it's not at all enough.
I can't move out because I don't have the money. Staying with friends would only be possible for a few days, and I feel so ashamed that my entire being is saying I'm just a burden - which makes asking for help even tougher. But I can't stay here and risk becoming so violent again. I scared myself. I'm really confused because while I feel so ashamed of myself, I also still feel angry. I'm typing this with cold hands. I just want to live in a place where I can turn the heat up to a comfortable level and trust that nobody will eat my leftovers. I want to be free. I don't want to be told my thoughts are stupid.
I know I should go to therapy. Unfortunately, I have no money for that and insurance-covered therapy is incredibly hard to find. Even if I get a spot, there's bound to be a six-months wait. I don't know what to do. I already go to a free counseling session every three weeks or so, but that's just not enough. I have been depressed for a long time. I have ADHD (didn't take my meds for that the last couple of days, which is probably connected to the outburst?) and I'm burnt out. I really need help no longer being a person I look down on.
Any thoughts would be appreciated, particularly if you have stories about people who used to be violent. I created an email address in case you'd like to answer anonymously:
[email protected]
Please, please be gentle. I  already feel like I'm a force of evil in the world.
posted by
Heartbroken
to
Human Relations
(25 answers total)
4 users marked this as a favorite
</post>

<post>
Title: Game of Telephone Luddite

Body:
Partner hates the notion of 'passing on messages', whether as passer-on or passer-ee. Curious if this is offensive behavior on my part or not. Some examples below.
1. A mutual friend (/my acquaintance) was coming over to hang out with partner. I had work with mutual-friend over the weekend and we chatted about their coming over (friend invited me to join them for beer at the beer-drinking part of their hangout, mainly out of politeness). I realized belatedly the next day that I had an appointment and asked partner to pass on my apologies and well wishes for something friend mentioned. Partner's mood turned sour and sarcastic and he refused, saying something along the lines of that's not his job and if I had something to say to someone I need to tell them myself.
2. My work (a very small business) sometimes employs partner as a contractor. We do all the organizing in the business in a group chat, and otherwise the emails/admin person emails the contractors (all friends, casual to close). Sometimes if we're organizing something in the group chat involving partner, for example a meeting, they'll ask if I can ask partner if he's free at this time, since we're usually together and so things can be organized immediately. Partner absolutely hates the 'he-said-she-said thing', 'chinese whispers' and how we're 'always talking about other people as if they're not there' (as in, that they talk about him as a 3rd party when asking me to ask him, instead of addressing him directly if they have a question) and says if something involves him, admin person should ask him themselves. He thinks it's an extra level of communication for them to ask me to ask him; I think it's the same level of communication, since it's either me or the admin person asking him, and so I might as well since it's faster.
He says that I'm so used to it at my work I can't even see how wrong it is, and that he finds it alien and revolting. But I'm pretty sure being asked to pass along apologies/messages or ask someone something if they're with me is just something I've always done.
Personality-wise he's quite rigid about things and I'm fairly go-with-the-flow though so I'm not sure if this is actually something offensive that's passed me by that shouldn't have.
So what's normal here?
posted by

<post>
Title: Wife and I have different feelings about Traveling

Body:
How can my wife and I navigate different interests and views on traveling?
My wife and I generally have a very good relationship.  We don't have kids.  Work is decent for both of us and we are middle aged.  Throughout most of our relationship we haven't done a ton of major travel.  Did Hawaii for our honeymoon and have done a bunch of shorter driving trips as well as visiting family a lot.  As of recently my wife is starting to take an interest in Disney cruises and international travel.  She's a die hard Disney fan with a season pass to Disneyland.  I am not into Disney unfortunately.  I don't hate it...I just don't love it enough to go there multiple times a year or take cruises all the time.   We did our 1st Disney cruise last year together.  It was ok.  My wife loved it...I didn't love it.  Didn't like the Disney aspect or the whole Cruise environment.  Of course during the cruise my wife had us put down a deposit on another cruise.
Eventually I told her I had no desire to go on the next cruise but said if we do one in the future to Alaska I'd be interested in that.  So she's going on a Disney cruise with a bunch of friends.  And that's great.  She'll have fun on the cruise, I'll have fun hanging at home and doing it up bachelor style.  I'm very introverted so for me that's a vacation, hahah.
My wife is now also thinking of taking a trip to Asia.  I hate flying, as I have a fear of flights.  And to make something pretty out in the open...I don't generally love taking big trips.  I just don't find it to be relaxing or enjoyable.  I find it to be stressful.  From the packing, making arangements for pets, making all the plans, to coming back and playing catchup.  Also the cost...we aren't poor but I think her opinion on taking these trips isn't considering the cost at least not in a serious way.
At the end of the day I want my wife to be happy.  She doesn't seem to have an issue with me not going on the next cruise.  Questions....Do I need to figure out a way to get myself to go on some of these cruises and trips...in effort to at least show her support with what she enjoys?  Is it fair to at some point say hey we need to find places and trips we both enjoy?  Is it also fair to say hey it's ok to take these trips whether together or alone but there needs to be a cap from a financial perspective?  Is it ok to sit out some trips just because...I don't enjoy them?
posted by
ljs30
to
Human Relations
(17 answers total)
2 users marked this as a favorite
</post>

prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: Feeling ashamed of myself and scared I might lose old friends.

Body:
Had a really bad day. Wondering if I'm actually not a good friend. I need some honest feedback on my behavior and maybe some advice for getting more organized. I'm too old to be this scattered :/
Yesterday was an old high school friend's birthday. She invited me, my partner, and one more friend to a waterpark. I agreed happily. While it was an hour away, I love my old friends and was sure it'd be fun. I asked my sister to check on the dogs and take them out midday. (I would not leave my dogs home alone for 11 hours, but knew they'd be fine for two stretches of five hours.)
The day was very fun for the most part, but I inconvenienced my friends in so many different ways, and I feel awful about it. Here's a complete list:
- made them wait in the car for twentyfive minutes because I wasn't ready on time (we carpooled)
- best friend used my bathroom while waiting, lots of dog hair on the floor and dishes in the bathtub
- asked for a ten-minute detour to a store because I forgot my contacts (this might've been okay because both friends seemed happy to get snacks there)
- slowest to shower pre-pool, they waited another five minutes or so
- after first hour of swimming: AWOL for 30 minutes making calls because sister had overslept and I had to make arrangements to get her to my house quickly
- texting sister between rides because I had left the wrong key, and she needed instructions for how to get in
In summary: I was in communication with my sister between 1:40 and 3:50, exchanging 44 short text messages and talking on the phone for a total of five minutes. Total pool time was from noon to seven. My friends did not even bring their phones to the pool. I felt strained and anxious between 2 and 4. I feel like I didn't bring my best self to this birthday party, and that I let my friends down. This feeling is exacerbated by the fact that I sent apologetic messages to both friends yesterday. While the birthday girl at least reacted with a heart emoji, my best friend did not react at all. This is scary. He's like a brother to me. I'm worried that he was shocked by the bathroom, or heard some pre-drive bickering between me and my partner, or just got so tired of waiting that he's really upset. Making people wait is probably my worst flaw. I asked him if he's okay just now. But I'm scared of his reply, and yes, I know I sound like a teenager.
(I was already feeling fragile before all this because I had a first session with a potential new therapist the day before. He implied my depression is self-inflicted and activated my rejection sensitivity by saying it seems like I'm abdicating responsibility for taking care of myself, and that he does not want that burden. The unconditional love and acceptance my best friend usually provides is a strong antidote to the feeling of being a burden on the world, so these things seem connected in my mind.)

prompt:

<post>
Title: Is it worth revisiting the unpleasant past?

Body:
I was with a guy for 8 years, a decade ago. I
asked a question
about him here in 2012. We eventually broke up for good a few years after that. I have moved on, my life is so much happier, but I still carry a lot of unresolved rage from that time. It's only now, like this month, that I fully understand the pervasiveness of his emotional abuse. I'm wondering what to do about it, if anything.
I was 20f and he was 26 when we met. I came from a strict, conservative minority background, he was my first boyfriend, a forbidden white guy. At the time we broke, up I felt like I was the bad guy. That I had myself become an abuser because I started weeping uncontrollably and blocking the door when he attempted to walk away from me during a fight. Because I smacked him on the arm once without much force, while he was yelling in my face. I instantly felt sick with guilt as soon as it happened, apologised repeatedly, and he never let me forget I was an abuser after that. I spent a long time after we broke up trying to work on myself, my "craziness".
For the past 5.5 years, I have been in a healthy relationship. I spent much of the first year hesitantly expressing myself. Asking, "is that okay?" before any action or idea. My current partner was mildly bemused and a touch concerned. I had an inkling at this time that what went wrong in my previous relationship wasn't all my fault. Some therapy helped me develop that perspective further. My viewpoint started to become more balanced and I developed a healthy anger at my ex.
I'm now almost 40. It's only in the last couple of weeks that I've sat down to read 'Why Does He Do That?' by Lundy Bancroft. I had assumed it wouldn't really apply to me because I wasn't "really abused", he was just an asshole sometimes. But as I've read more and more of it, I've been feeling sick. My ex was never violent. He always framed his complaints as care and sensitivity. I was shocked to see so many of his behaviours and characteristics spelled out plainly as abuse. It's validating and relieving, but mostly I feel rage, expressed by wanting to burst into tears all the time.
What really kills me is that I lost my friends because of him. We had a circle of close, mutual friends. Those friends did not take sides, we tried not to involve them, but a couple of years after we broke up I moved away from the city where they all still live, back to my home country. We kept in touch sporadically, a couple of them even came to stay with me, but once I started understanding what had happened, I felt like I couldn't be myself around them anymore. Even my ex himself! A few months after I moved home, I flew back to our shared city for a reunion, it was all jolly water-under-the-bridge vibes, he and I shared a nice chat and a hug. I was still so deluded at the time. I hate that he thinks I still have respect for him.
I just disappeared from everyone's lives, stopped replying to messages. I didn't want to potentially ruin their friendships with my ex because he was always a wonderful friend to them, and I'm the one who's far away anyway. Why stir up drama? But I have hated feeling like the bad guy. They are good, smart, kind people who would have given me a fair hearing. But also, their bonds with him will only have deepened over the years, I assume. He was always a good, kind friend to them, the abuse was carefully hidden. It's quite possible, even, that he has told them I abused him, or would bring that out if I ever explained my side to them.
So I have been telling myself, these last couple of weeks, that the rage will subside. Let sleeping dogs lie, don't stir up trouble. I have this rage-driven urge to speak my truth. To email my three closest friends from that time and lay it out for them. How I feel now, why I left. Explaining how I don't need or expect anything from them in response. Which by now I don't, I truly believe. It would just feel so freeing to be truthful and open. But I get that it's a powder keg, I have no way of controlling the impact of my "truth bomb" (ugh I hate that phrase but it's apt).
So I'm telling myself not to rage and it's not working, because I still have these validation fantasies of speaking my truth. Please can you help me manage these feelings? How do I learn to live with the status quo?

prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: How do I handle uncertainty during likely breakup?

Body:
My (male early 40s) partner of 12 years (female early 40s) came to me a couple of weeks ago and said she was unhappy with her life, wanted to make big changes, and was having doubts about me as a partner. Despite her claim that she's not breaking up with me, I'm devastated. How should I get through this period of uncertainty?
Some things I'm trying:
- Talking with her honestly about how I'm feeling
- Listening to her talk about how she's feeling
- Meditation
- Affirmations
- Therapy
- Exercise (though it's been tough as I'm not eating very much)
- SSRIs (I've been struggling more and more with anxiety/depression, which has been a problem for our relationship)
- Talking on the phone with friends
- Distractions
- Believing her when she says she loves me and is not breaking up with me
- Couples counseling (starting next week)
Some things that make it feel like a breakup:
- She says she loves me but is not in love with me
- She's not excited to make an effort to fall back in love with me
- She says she doesn't feel like we understand each other and doesn't think we will understand one another
- She doesn't think we're compatible
- She thinks I've prioritized the relationship so much I've lost a sense of self
- She feels like she hasn't been prioritizing me and doesn't want that to continue, but also doesn't want to start prioritizing me
- She wants to do a lot of things I don't want to do (like go on a three-month trip) but doesn't feel it's fair to ask me to stay behind
Some things I'm mad about:
- She seemed disappointed that I reacted so strongly (I cried for about four days)
- She thinks I'm hyper-fixated on us breaking up and I keep bringing it up because I'd rather break up than face change or some of the problems with our relationship/compatibility
- Some of her behavior that seemed fine when I felt secure in the relationship now seems dismissive and disrespectful
Because this came on so suddenly for both of us, I'm trying to give her some time to figure out what she actually wants before forcing the issue. But I'm having a hard time believing that she's not breaking up with me (albeit slowly). And, frankly, after typing a lot of that out I'm having a hard time thinking that we shouldn't break up. Some of those things seem like dealbreakers.
I haven't pushed to break up, though, because:
- I'm still in love with her
- We've treated each other really well over twelve years and made an amazing life together
- Over the past week we've been more open and honest than we have been in a while, and that felt really good
- I think it's worth going to couples therapy after 12 good years, a house we own together, and a dog
- She says I'm the best thing that's ever happened to her and I feel the same about her
- I'm not ready to lose her
In my better moments I feel like I'm getting back in touch with myself a little bit, finding some identity and self-love and self-support. I'm also deepening other connections and recognizing some unhealthy ways I've been retreating from the world. And I really do admire her honesty and want to give her the space to figure out what she really wants so we can come together and see if it matches up with what I really want.
In my worse moments I'm overwhelmed by sadness and despair and feel like I've lost my one chance to be happy in a relationship (or maybe at all).

<post>
Title: Comfortable-with-conflict + Conflict-avoidant. How can it work?

Body:
My new partner and I have different conflict styles and I’m finding it hard to navigate. I’m conflict avoidant and cry easily, where he sees yelling as a natural way of expressing how one’s feeling. I’m working on being more emotionally resilient these last few years and have made fairly significant (to me) progress – I can take being screamed at fairly nonchalantly now for example - but struggle with it in a relationship context.
He's frustrated with:
. My lack of emotional resilience – when voices are raised and (what I perceive as) contempt is shown I cry. Things that are barely disagreements to him I see as large conflicts – he thinks this is making mountains out of molehills
. For him, the anger blows over and is finished. For me, the fight-or-flight chemicals/cortisol leave me drained and unhappy for a few hours until my body finishes processing
. That after a rage, it seems to wipe out the good feelings he's built up with me and his progress is erased
. He thinks my desire for every day to be happy and conflict-free is ridiculous, as conflict is a normal part of every day life
On my part I struggle with:
. The way he talks to me when he’s feeling raised emotions is so confronting to me – even at my angriest I've never come close to speaking to anyone like he does to me when he’s mildly annoyed
. I’m wired to go out of my way to prevent ‘bad’ things from happening (I’ll overthink all the things that could go wrong in a situation before it happens), so this new norm of constant conflict is miserable because I can’t prevent them
. It feels like I’m struggling to get to the ‘I love you’ stage because I think I need a more constant uninterrupted happiness, and when I feel conflict I lock up inside to feel safe. Our sex life has been suffering as I don’t feel sexual when I’m in this state – I finish him every day/every other day but don’t really want him to touch me
. I also can’t figure out how to have relationship conversations - he sees it/the way I do it as me starting drama and conflict
Culturally I’d say he is more high-conflict than the norm where we are. He’s notorious in his line of work for yelling at people (for being what he thinks is lazy or not doing the right thing), and has been in trouble for it before. I occasionally have to mouth apologies to cashiers/baristas/service people as we leave due the way he spoke to them if they’ve done something he deemed unacceptable (not knowing their product well enough, interrupting our conversation even if we’re the ones in the wrong by standing in the way, being ‘incompetent’, etc). It surprised me when he said he’d been asked to leave by a cafe staff once – I thought the number would be higher.
Example of a conflict: I once left a spoon in the sink thinking I’d wash it up with the dishes after dinner. He slammed a door and screamed at me for being thoughtless about a shared space – his expectation is that everything no matter how small is washed immediately after using/eating, ideally during cooking. He hadn’t said so explicitly but felt I should have realised by observing him, as he had been thoughtfully doing for me.
More commonly something will trigger him and he’ll stew in a quiet contemptuous rage for a few hours. I’ll ask him if I’ve done something to annoy him or make him mad, and to tell me please so I can fix it. He’ll say that it’s nothing/not a big deal and sometime after seemingly get over it when he’s decided he’s done being mad about it.
I find it hard to figure out how to defuse these situations. He said there are three ways to get a guy to do what you want but that I don’t know any of them. One of them is apparently that if he’s yelling at me, don’t engage; just look bored, raise an eyebrow and ask him pointedly if he’s done - if not [I’ll] be waiting here until he is. That would  take the wind out of his sails and he’d stop yelling and start talking (though sometimes he wouldn’t be done and will need to yell some more until he is). I’d never encountered anyone who yells like he does so I couldn’t have imagined that as a response – it seemed contemptuous and condescending to me, though he’d probably prefer that to my people pleasing tendencies.
To his credit I can tell that while he’s deeply annoyed by some things I do, he tries hard to let it go. He’s said that he’s felt a deep sense of anger towards the world since maybe 20 years ago, and it’s clear he tries not to let the anger out.
I guess I’m looking for anecdotes, advice and resources on emotional resilience and finding a common ground.

How to self soothe and immediately help myself when I feel like I'm doing something wrong and it triggers a trauma response?

I want to stop this immediately. I know I want to be with her, and I know I am self sabotaging. She has pointed out to me how scary this is for her, and how it doesn't seem like I will ever understand. She is worried that this emotional behaviour will also lead to other boundary pushing on my part.   I know this stems from a scary first few years with my mother as child.
If you have encountered this in your partner, or have experienced it yourself, do you have advice how you dealt with it?

<post>
Title: playing with your friends?

Body:
my new partner is interested in a new friendship that makes me uncomfortable. (how) do i deal?
i (nb, queer, as is everyone in this story) have been dating sam for six months after meeting though a mutual hobby. sam is wonderful and sweet and things are going very well. we are monogamous.
we both recently met joe though said mutual hobby. joe and sam connected, hung out together once while i was at work, and started texting/messaging. recently, a week or two into their friendship, sam told me that joe had invited us to a play party, phrasing it something like, i’m not sure if you and anonymous are interested, but i can get you invites to this private play party i’m going to. joe did say they invited another friend from our community, and sam pointed out that joe invited both of us, but to me it felt like the invitation was directed at sam, with me as a polite/necessary accessory. sam responded that they had been wanting to go to a play party but demurred. i told sam that joe's invitation made me uncomfortable, like joe was shooting his shot to see if sam would be interested in taking their relationship to a sexual space (literally and perhaps figuratively). sam had not previously told joe that they are interested in play parties, though they are (and have not been; i have, though only once).
joe then invited sam/us to another play party, telling joe that they had invited another couple we know. i started to feel more uncomfortable, and sam told joe that though they are interested in play parties, they only want to go with me and don’t want to go with anyone else they know. joe responded by saying, in part, i hope i didn’t make you uncomfortable, i go to play parties with platonic friends all the time, i can see how you would think it was an attempt to hook up if you’ve never been, etc
i feel like this response was disingenuous and condescending. in my opinion, play parties are not spaces that you go to with just any friend, they are spaces you go to with friends you are comfortable/interested in viewing/participating in sexual content around/with.* if you go with a friend, maybe you’d play together or maybe you wouldn’t, but overall it’s still a sexual space. and many friends do play with one another and consider it platonic.
sam is very reassuring about the fact that they only want to be sexual with me, but i feel incredibly uncomfortable around joe, such that i am limiting my engagement in our hobby, which sucks. to me, joe seems like someone who shot their shot and is now being disingenuous about it, and i don’t like that. i also don’t like that sam doesn’t see it that way (though they say they understand my perspective) and thinks joe is a really genuine person who wanted to pass along a cool invite. sam has been slowing down their contact with joe because of my discomfort but has been clear that they do want to be friends with joe.
i have been learning to trust my intuition, which is often borne out to be prescient, and my hackles are seriously raised by joe in a very intense unpleasant ruminative way.** i feel uneasy imagining a future in which sam and joe are close. sam feels like the issue is that i don’t trust them. my conscious reality is that i don’t trust joe, but i do see that in order for something untoward to happen between joe and sam, sam would need to be a willing participant, so i suppose on some level i don’t yet fully trust sam.
so, mefi, am i just being super square and insecure and sex-negative? do i just need to get over this? if so, how? and/or are there boundaries i could set/requests i could make that would respect sam’s autonomy and freedom but minimize my anxiety?***
thank you!
*i realize that for some people, this could be all of their friends, and perhaps herein lies the rub
**i have an intake appointment with a psychiatrist next week to be evaluated for ocd
***already in therapy

<post>
Title: Why do some people "feel" like alcoholics to me, even when they're not?

Body:
[Obvious TW for substance abuse] Sometimes I feel that people I encounter have the same emotional "heat signature" as my alcoholic family members, even when I'm certain or reasonably certain they do not have substance-use disorders. Am I just projecting my own issues, or do other adult  children of addicts experience this too?
I grew up with an alcoholic parent, in an extended family with an extensive history of addiction. I realise it's common for people from this background to be attracted/attractive to people with substance-use disorders (romantically or platonically), but that's not quite what I'm trying to describe. Periodically I'll encounter someone at work, socially, whatever, and within a couple interactions I can sense
something
that reminds me powerfully, on a gut level, of my loved ones who are/have been addicts. As I get to know these people better they frequently turn out not to be in any kind of active addiction, but the gut feeling persists. (They also frequently seem to like me, even if I don't especially want to befriend them, but this could again be projection.)
This sensed similarity seems to manifest as a certain emotional intensity, maybe mixed with depressive or moody tendencies. But...a lot of other people are intense, or melancholy, or whatever, and they don't all set off this sense of recognition in me? Do any other family members of addicts experience this? If so, what do you think it is?
I guess I'm asking this question because I'm trying to be a lot more mindful and proactive about how I choose and nurture my interpersonal relationships, and I'm wondering if I can really trust my ability to sort out natural affinity from the desire to repeat comforting but unhealthy patterns. Thanks.

prompt:

<post>
Title: Whole life fallen apart 30s edition™

Body:
I've been through one of the hardest years of my life and a recent break up has triggered a near breakdown which has me feeling I don't know where to go next.
First, I previously posted about my relationship:
https://ask.metafilter.com/384748/Future-relationship-talk-didnt-go-as-Id-hoped
Turns out most of you were right and we broke up 8 days ago. We did reach the point where we had a plan and I was interviewing for jobs in his city, but when push came to shove he panicked and broke up with me. He gave me a bunch of excuses including that I didn't clean the way he did and that I didn't eat pork which doesn't work for him cooking for two people long-term. Frustratingly, some of the stuff he raised, we actually resolved on the call, but it was too late now because instead of having a 'let's talk out these issues' talk, he went nuclear.
The last time I physically saw him two weeks ago, I had no indicated anything was wrong. He even gave me an engagement-style ring which he emphasised was a 'gift.' Family and friends asked if I was engaged because it was so striking.
He wants to remain friends but I don't think I can, at least not right now. I still love him so much. He said I was wonderful, the best relationship of his life and that he loved me. He also said he'd noticed some bad controlling habits cropping up that had arisen in his marriage and he didn't want to put me through that (yes, I had noticed this - but at least he was self-aware and you can do therapy in a relationship).
Other things that happened to me in the last year:
-My beloved cat of 19 years old died (had her since I was a kid).
- My terminally ill relative died in January. I then had to wait a month for the funeral/was embroiled in funeral planning. We were very close.
- The
day
I returned from compassionate leave my workplace told me they were letting me go. No issues had ever been raised in my frequent one to ones with the manager who had recently gone on maternity leave. It was a big shock as I've never been fired before.
- My aunt died unexpectedly.
- The break up.
- The year before last, my good friend died from breast cancer.
One good thing
- my first novel is supposed to be published next year, but now I'm nervous about that panning out too!And yes, the ex asked me to send a copy...
I had the good sense to save up to 6 months of my salary, but once the end of summer comes I'll be in trouble. The job market is tough.
The last time, I saw my ex, I had the courage to tell him how I was feeling. How I was scared of not being able to pay bills. That I had lost the daily camaraderie of being with my team, and now I couldn't afford to see friends because that costs too. I told him I felt isolated and scared. He told me I shouldn't feel inadequate, that I'm enough. But after the break up he isn't exactly selling this.
Now at 33 having to start over I'm also dealing with the reality I might not ever have kids - it won't mean life over, but I'd like to have the chance. In my 20s, I lived in a bunch countries. I came home to Scotland just before Covid hit and lots of good things happened - hell, 2023 was the best year of my life. But now I can't get enthused about anything or even about living here. How do I decide where to turn next, or how to start asking myself the necessary questions to reach a better life?
therapy isn't really an option right now, due to cost.

<post>
Title: If a loved one got panic attacks, would you accommodate them in any way?

Body:
I have a panic disorder. It's awful because I really think I'm about to die when objectively, there's barely even a problem. I don't want to panic. It feels scary, embarrassing, and I don't want to scare others. I've asked my husband for help, but he just keeps talking about his right to not be controlled.
I get it, partly. I become aggressive sometimes, and if someone said to me, "Be quiet
now
, unless you want me to flip out", I would feel manipulated. At the same time, I thought he'd want to help me get better. I've learned skills that will reduce the severity of the attacks, but I'm not Gandhi. I can't (yet) use mindfulness practices while I'm being talked at. All sounds and sensations become grating. So I repeatedly asked for some quiet time to downregulate, and he responded since I'm the one with the problem, I need to solve it myself. It just feels really dismissive and not loving.
Last night, he started filming me when I lost it, and it feels like he enjoys seeing me lose control. I'm honestly debating leaving my marriage, and this is a big part of the reason. I just don't feel supported in my mental health struggles. I desperately want to get better and be better.
My husband is very likely autistic. Is all that rigidity about rights and rules possibly connected to that?

<post>
Title: I feel like a lost child.

Body:
I had a terrible day and really need to feel comforted. I talked to my best friend and I've been browsing YouTube in bed with dogs around me. I took a shower and listened to loud, happy music. I cried a lot and shared my frustration. I still don't feel better. I think my therapist accidentally activated some major childhood trauma today, and my formerly successful skills are failing me.
I've been attending a mental health programme with music therapy, dance, CBT, gym, and mindfulness classes five days a week. It's helping me fight depression and burnout. But today, my therapist said the team decided I'll be done in two weeks, not four. They said at the start (six weeks ago) that it's decided on a case-by-case basis, and it sounds like they think I just won't make more progress than I already have (they agree I've made progress up to now). But I feel abandoned, and it's the weekend now, and I'm really not okay. I feel like I did something wrong. I don't know what that might be though, because I'm definitely not disrupting the process or causing problems. I follow their advice when I can and I'm honest when I can't (for example, I can sense they want me to end my marriage, and that topic is just so overwhelming tp me). Up until yesterday, I felt like everything was fine. In fact, I've never felt more at-ease in a group setting. I was even allowing for the possibility that I'm valuable to the group and likeable.
The worst part is that no therapist or other staff member approached me after I got the news, even though I was obviously extremely upset (first tearing up constantly, eventually withdrawing). As a kid, I remember desperately needing someone to see my distress. The people at this clinic act like very good parents most of the time, caring and respectful of themselves and others. They usually approach people and offer a conversation or something soothing (like some lavender oil to smell or whatever). Today, I felt disliked and rejected. My favourite therapist wasn't in, and I hated the idea of everyone voting me off the island. Another patient had to talk me down, and that was awkward because I don't want to be a burden. And then everyone went home.
I really need a hug, but I don't want to lean on my husband because I agree our relationship isn't healthy. I need to ask myself difficult questions about the situation with him, so I don't want to accept any comfort at the moment. He hurt me badly last week (emotionally), and I don't know if I can forgive him. I don't really have anyone else currently close enough for hugs.
Any thoughts? Please be gentle, I'm very fragile.

prompt:

<post>
Title: Future relationship talk didn’t go as I’d hoped.

Body:
After a talk about the future of the relationship, I’m not sure whether he just needs more time or if this is a classic case where he doesn’t see a long term future with me for whatever reason. We are both early 30s.
I am in a relationship with a man I adore. It has been different with him since day one and he feels like family. I’ve felt consistently safe and loved in the face of a hard year. My elderly cat died (she loved him and gave her permission!), then my grandmother who was something between grandparent and parent died, and then I was  laid off the day I returned from compassionate leave.
He has been amazing through all of it. He is also a successful hard worker and a kind person - perhaps I should also mention he is high functioning. We have gone on several trips together that were fun and easy, and while working remotely I was able to be with him for weeks at a time. Being in each others space for prolonged periods has been very easy too. My parents also love him and that’s a first with both!
But now I want more. We’re long distance and roughly see each other every two weeks for 3-4 days. Leaving is getting harder. I miss him and companionship, and feel lonely. Furthermore, I haven’t met his family. They live in another country but it’s only a 1.5 hour flight.
I find myself approaching a brick wall when I try to discuss the future. The first time I brought it up was 11 months in. This was too early for him and he said let’s wait a few months.
During a long weekend break last week I raised it again because now that I’m on the job market again I said I’d like to include his city in my search, otherwise we’re staring at more years apart. He said he would be happy to take on most of the travelling to me if I end up in my own city again, but also looking in his city would be fine.
At this point, we have not solidly stated whether we want marriage and kids. I have always been on the fence, but I am moving in that direction the longer we are together. And I decided I’d like to discuss this with him.
For the second time, he said he wanted to wait and have this conversation at a less stressful time in my life. He asked if this would be ok, I said no, it wouldn’t, as he keeps pushing the conversation back. He talks about having kids often enough I didn’t think it would be a leap to discuss it.
Ultimately, I was disappointed by his response. I suppose I wanted him to take my hand reassuringly and say he was ready now. Instead he said he loves me and spending time with me but that taking this next step would be serious and need a lot of conversation. He has been divorced before (she divorced him, the are still friends now). I am really bummed out that the thought of planning a future together didn’t excite him.
We left it with him saying let’s come up with a timeline when we see each other later this month but I do feel dejected.
How worried should I be at his reluctance to plan together in our early 30s a bit shy of 2 years in? And should I be handling these conversations differently? I don’t want to feel like I’m strong arming someone into commitment.
posted by
BuffySummers
to
Human Relations
(34 answers total)
</post>

<post>
Title: Recommendation for a therapist for relationship indecision

Body:
I’m looking for a therapist who specialises in relationship OCD or relationship anxiety/indecision. I’d like to do telehealth/Zoom consults, so they could be anywhere in the world.
I have some pretty severe relationship anxiety, possibly relationship OCD (which is basically OCD, but where you obsess over whether your relationship is right for you). I tried seeing a marriage and relationship psychologist, but she just really didn’t understand where I was coming from and hadn’t actually heard of relationship OCD. I also saw a general OCD psychologist. Although he had heard of relationship OCD, he wasn’t confident that this was my problem, but admitted that he didn't normally work with clients on relationship issues (he referred me on to the above-mentioned relationship psychologist). So, I'm not sure what to do next, but I feel like I would really benefit from someone who is a specialist in relationship indecision and anxiety and has kind of "seen it all" here.
Unfortunately, my problem is just sufficiently weird that I don’t think most therapists know what to say about it. I basically am in a happy long-term relationship, but have had off-and-on doubts which I can’t resolve. But the doubts are very amorphous, sometimes just being a feeling of something “not being right”. I’ve thought about leaving a few times, but in the end I can’t bring myself to leave someone I adore based on the oscillations of my admittedly very neurotic brain.
Obsessive googling and reading books hasn’t helped this, and so I really just want to find someone who can work with me to sort it out.

prompt:

<post>
Title: Resentment over intermittent ghosting

Body:
I resent my friend’s intermittent ghosting, especially during bereavement.
I’ve been friends with R for 22 years - I’m in my early 30s now, so since we were kids. He’s a straight cis man and I’m a cis woman.
As well as having much in common, we both went through break ups and bereavements - I’d say he was my closest confidante and his friendship helped me through these times.
In our twenties, we both moved to the same European country. I went first, he followed with his partner a few years later. We then spent one holiday a year together with partners and friends. But he became flaky and we argued more than once about him cancelling plans last minute.
He split up with his partner of a decade in 2023. He had also lost his aunt. I visited him for a few days. After this visit, I feel the ghosting started. I still heard from him at Christmas and New Year, but then nothing.
Finally, in October I contacted him one more time saying I felt he was ghosting and I’d like to address the issue if there was one. He replied saying he was upset that I’d think he was ghosting. He said he had had a breakdown, had gone through treatment, and was doing much better.
When I replied again, nothing. Three months later, he sent me a song about a woman with my eye colour saying ‘This always reminds me of you’. So I replied, and he sent a voice message back. He wanted to know how I was and to catch up.
The truth is that recent months have been very hard. I have been helping to care for a terminal relative. So I told him this, indicating she was in the last  days/weeks of her life. I then told him some more positive news and asked for his.
Since then, he hasn’t replied and my relative has since died. I acknowledge I’m grieving but still I can’t believe he couldn’t even muster an ‘I’m sorry’ or anything sympathetic.
I find the sensation of being demoted from close friend to acquaintance quite hard to take. I feel he controls the friendship. I’m not good at grey areas and feel stuck in a way.
posted by
BuffySummers
to
Human Relations
(17 answers total)
5 users marked this as a favorite
</post>

prompt:

<post>
Title: How do I stop thinking about him? (Literally)

Body:
I would like to stop thinking about my ex, but
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
memory wipes aren't a real thing. What's the next best thing in the real world?
I think about my ex every day, pretty consistently throughout the day. I wouldn't describe the experience as having intrusive thoughts, it's more like my brain "defaults" to it very easily. It's like there is a computer program dedicated to thinking about him running in the background at all times. The nature of the thoughts varies. Sometimes it's ruminating about confusing or painful things that remain unresolved for me with regard to our relationship. Sometimes it's replaying pleasant memories. Sometimes it's just a random neutral memory. Sometimes it's imagining how it would be to run into him on the street. There is no one consistent thing that my mind returns to -- it's more that overall, the volume is  A Lot. If the procedure in the
Eternal Sunshine
movie existed, I would opt for it with regard to him.
I would like to stop thinking about him in the literal sense. I would like to develop an ability to, as it were, change the channel mentally when a thought of him arises. I know there are a number of CBT techniques that are useful for this sort of thing (interruption, redirection), but I would like further tips, ideally from your own experience, on concrete ways of using these strategies.
A lot of the CBT worksheets and such I have looked at are largely focused on engaging with the content of the negative thoughts, whether thought challenging/reality testing, reframing, mindfulness, etc. I specifically don't want to engage with the content of my thoughts about my ex. I want the best strategies for redirection, ideally with an eye to, over time, minimizing how readily my mind reaches for this particular set of memories. For example, maybe you have dealt with something like this and found that redirecting to reciting poetry works well, or maybe visualizing some mental cue like, well, changing the channel.  Or hopping on one leg. Or some kind of effective negative conditioning (I have tried the rubber band on the wrist thing and it didn't really work). The more specific the better -- I would love to try different things and see if they work for me or can be adapted into something that works for me.
I am not interested in advice on how else to approach or think about this predicament (so, please, no advice about therapy or suggestions along the lines of, if I resolve my feelings about him, the thoughts will attenuate organically). I just want to retrain my brain out of this habit, and would be grateful for your tried and true cognitive hacks to aid me in doing so.
Thanks in advance!

Human Relations

17 users marked this as a favorite

prompt:
Analyze this advice forum post and extract the following information:

<post>
Title: New couples moving in together quickly

Body:
Recently I have heard of a few new couples, including cases where one or both have kids from other relationships, moving in together very early in the relationship. I think my questions boil down to these: this is not great, right? and, also, is this happening more, or am I just noticing it more? And, also, maybe, what are folks thinking, if most of us (right?) know it's not great? I know sometimes it's financial, but also maybe they're caught up in new relationship energy? (I hope this isn't chatfilter.)
The situations I'm describing involve monogamous people and both gay and straight couples.
A college friend of mine (we are both middle aged) had essentially an emotional affair with a coworker on and off over a few years, including a stint where he and his wife broke up for a month and he dated the other person then (so, an actual, very brief, sexual relationship). He and his wife finally decided to divorce, and he moved out of the family home and moved right in with his new partner. The kids are teens.
Another friend told me about a same-sex couple she knows where they were together many years, have kids, and, as they are moving out from each other, both are about to start cohabitating with new partners. The kids are in middle school and high school.
Yet another friend told me that, fresh on the heels of her divorce and coming out, she moved in really quickly with a new partner, and the relationship crashed and burn, and it was super disruptive for her kids, and she regrets that.
I get that, after a long and unhappy relationship, new love can feel so surprising and intoxicating that it's hard to believe it's not eternal, and people sometimes make rash decisions. I also know there can be real financial and logistical benefits to a household with two adults. But, I'd also think in many of these cases, these are folks who want to do right by their kids and aren't necessarily responding only to financial pressure. I am wondering why people are doing this when it's so against the conventional wisdom (isn't it?). I wonder if it's because parents feel pressure to live with a partner instead of having someone over when the kids are in the house? Like, does that make the relationship seem more legitimate?
(I also want to be clear that I know this is none of my business, and I am definitely not sharing my opinions with any of the people I am talking about. I have been supportive of my college friend, actually. I am bringing this here because I am not talking to the folks involved about it all.)
(And yes, I was reminded of this because of
another recent question
, but that situation is completely different than what I am talking about!)
posted by
woolsocks
to
Human Relations
(29 answers total)
1 user marked this as a favorite
</post>

How do you handle someone who is emotionally abusive and using their child as a pawn?

Sister is sat watching from the car. I let Nephew in and sister drives off.
I’ve looked after Nephew a billion times before but very often Sister doesn’t ask. Nephew just turns up. I have repeatedly asked Sister to let me know if she wants me look after him. Sister thinks I don’t need any notice as I am off work anyway at the weekend.
So around 8 hours later when Sister arrived to collect Nephew, I asked her again to let me know beforehand. Sister claims she has sent messages or phoned yet there is no record on my phone. Sister has also told my mother that she doesn’t ask me in advance because it will give me the opportunity to say no. I have said no once in 11 years.
Sister starts to berate me that Nephew is only a boy staying in a room at my house that I don’t even need to speak to him and that Nephew is picking up on me being disgruntled, that she needs to work, that the government says she has to work, that she is a single mother etc. etc. Nephew comes down the stairs. <post>
Title: How to stop rumination, regret and comparison after a breakup?

Body:
About a year ago I broke up with a wonderful partner of 2 years (see
here
) because it had become clear to me over many months that I only had deeply platonic feelings for him.
I wrestled with trying to use my brain to override my gut for months, attempting to use logic and “loving actions” to generate the feelings of romantic interest I lacked, but ultimately failed. This is the first time I have been the one to break up a serious relationship.
Since then I have really struggled to stop ruminating over this decision. I still go to bed at night trying to soothe myself by remembering all the specific times the relationship felt wrong and still sometimes worry whether I self-sabotaged or just didn’t try hard enough. I feel like I’m stuck in this weird limbo between believing the breakup was the right thing to do, yet still not believing anything will ever match up again. I’m worried there is something fundamentally flawed with me which means I can’t just appreciate a good, healthy partnership. I often look around at other people and wonder why it seems so easy and natural for them.
I’ve been on a number of dates since the breakup, many of them pleasant, but none have progressed. Part of the reason for this is that I’m being super aggressive with cutting things after the first or second date if I’m not feeling a vibe. I think I’m terrified of ending up in another situation where I’ve overlooked issues at the beginning and then realised down the track that those issues meant the relationship couldn’t survive (I’m 32F).
I have been to some therapy sessions but would appreciate any input from anyone who’s been in a similar situation, found a way to stop this relentless rumination and/or found a good way to approach finding a new partner without comparison to their ex.

<post>
Title: Could my husband's paranoid anxiety improve?

Body:
My husband’s (trauma-based?) anxiety runs to paranoia, and he occasionally makes angry and hurtful accusations at me. None of the accusations are true and are not really based in reality. Could this get better?
My husband has been seeing a therapist who specialises in narcissistic abuse since spring of this year, following a set of realisations about past relationships and then decisions to cut contact with his best friend, his parents, and finally his only sibling. He tells me his therapist has tentatively suggested he may have cPTSD. Before he started therapy, he would in effect try to use me as his therapist and I have listened to him talk for many, many hours. I am sad that he has so few people in his life now but consider that he is better placed than I am to decide on the kind of relationships he should have with his family and friends.
My husband has also experienced IBS-related agoraphobia for about 8 years rarely leaving the house, and is entirely dependent on me financially. He came out to me, and my friends and family as bisexual early in the year. He is not engaging in any medical care except for his weekly therapist appointment on Zoom. We have sex very infrequently (and this is a mismatch for him) but otherwise have a very affectionate and loving relationship. He has always been supportive of me and been proud of my accomplishments inside and outside work. Before these very occasional accusations started happening, I felt generally like the character in
Alanis Morrissette’s Head over Feet
.
He clearly has symptoms of anxiety including physical symptoms such as feeling dizzy and sometimes expresses paranoid thoughts about eg tradespeople that come to the house. Very occasionally he is angry at me. Sometimes this will be with a raised voice, other times with what feels to me like quite cold-blooded venom, sometimes it will be preceded by an obvious short period of silent treatment. It is always a long, confusing monologue, with vague insinuations and an insistence that I know exactly what he is talking about. He frequently claims that people say things ‘subtextually’ and sometimes specifically that I have clearly communicated something related to his insinuations ‘subtextually’. Although I have never felt at risk of violence, when this anger happens I feel very physically frightened. I tend to remain silent, and my thoughts are focused on escape and the risks of escalation. I find his train of thought very difficult to follow, it is not concrete or specific and I am sometimes in panic mode. I am often very literal and am not sure that I really know what he means when he talks about things being ‘subtextual’. Eventually he will make a specific accusation, or I will say something and that will lead to an accusation.
The accusations so far have been
•	I am withholding sex deliberately to manipulate him
•	I lack empathy and am manipulative
•	I treat him badly in general and would be unhappy if he was no longer agoraphobic
•	I have been having casual relationships with other people since we met 12 years ago
•	I have at some point had a ‘secret relationship’ with a particular female friend.
The accusations are both unexpected and untrue.
After I have denied the accusation, eventually the anger will blow out and dissipate. There might follow another confusing monologue about his state of mind and the trauma he has experienced. Usually, we will then have a decent conversation (either immediately or the next morning) in which he provides some reasoning behind his accusation. They are generally based on very convoluted trains of logic and some snippet of a real-life event or comment. He interprets his accusations and my denials as a way of providing reassurance that I am not going to cause trauma like ‘everyone else’ has. He has some real sympathy for my being upset by them, but I am not convinced he understands how much they distress me. He has told me that wants me to have more empathy for his trauma and accept that he does not mean the accusations personally.
I find each anger and accusation event frightening at the time and destabilising afterwards. They have happened four or five times in this calendar year. Although I love him very much, I think that if they kept continuing, I would eventually want to leave. I am holding out hope that by continuing to work with his therapist they will stop at some point. Am I being wildly unrealistic? I recognise that I have a strong reaction to any anger. Is there anything I could do to reduce the impact it has on me in the meantime?
I unsuccessfully tried to persuade him to go to therapy for a very long time, and in the end, it was a friend of mine who convinced him, so my chances of talking him into any specific actions are low. But if he were asking for advice, what advice would you give?
In terms of my own real-life support, I

<post>
Title: Can't turn great meetups into anything more - suggestions?

Body:
I moved to a new city this year and seem to be having a hard time making connections ever since. It is not for lack of meeting people, however! A few times in recent months I have met someone, really enjoyed talking to them, and spent the better part of the day or night together with (I think!) a clear mutual interest. However, it always falls apart after that and I'm not sure what I am doing wrong. For context I am a straight dude.
For example, last week I met someone getting breakfast who was super nice and I really enjoyed chatting with her. I had to go about my day but before I left she asked for my number. We met later the same day and originally planned to only say hi but ended up talking for a few hours before finally going home for the evening. I texted her later that night, she responded right away, and we talked a bit more before I asked if she would like to get coffee in a few days. After that, radio silence and I am not sure how or if to follow up.
If this was a one time thing I would not think anything of it but a couple similar situations combined with this one have left me wondering what is going wrong? I can't help but to think that something about myself is putting people off, but I always feel like we have a really nice time in person when we meet, and then afterwards we aren't on the same page at all. Curious to know if other people have experienced this. I am doing fine and not even really searching for a relationship but it is really bugging me that these great people I meet (and think I connect very well with) rarely want to follow up.
Thanks!

<post>
Title: Should I move in with my dad and break up with my boyfriend, or no?

Body:
I am 31F and at a cross roads. I am living alone check to check and dating a man for 2.5 years. I am 20k in debt and he is 54k in debt. We were going to move in together in November when my lease is up, but I’ve woken up a bit and think I maybe should move in with my dad instead. I’m not sure if our financial situations will work together or lifestyle.
I am worried about my boyfriend and is future. Should I end it or is it workable?
We met online and have been dating 2.5 years. He lives one hour away. I’ve had several LTR but he’s only had one other 6 month relationship from college.
I grew up in a Midwest city and never left. Parents divorced, mom really mentally ill and illiterate so I grew up with my dad, dad was abusive and neglectful, stepmom abusive, mom too. I moved out in 2017 at 24 and am now 32F and in $20k federal student loan debt (originally 24k, graduated in 2020) with a BA in Communications. I rent an apartment for $960 by myself with two cats. I only make $53k as a customer operations coordinator but am working on a career change to maybe project management to make more, though it has been rough in this job market. Many interviews no offers. I only have $7.2k in retirement and $400 to my name. My dad was wonderful and paid off my $3.5k credit card last week after my mom told him I’m not doing good financially and he reached out, and I’ve locked up the card.
My boyfriend grew up one hour north on a family farm next to a small town of 2k. His dad was a maintenance worker and mom on disability or had admin jobs. His parents divorced this year and his mom is living on couches and out of hotels. My boyfriend is 35M and $54k in private student loan debt (originally $84k, started college in 2007, not sure when he stopped) with an AA in Applied Science. He originally went to a university for engineering just like his older sister did but couldn’t pass the math classes, but got into the party scene, got arrested a few times, his Facebook is full of posts from long ago about getting and being drunk and “let’s fuck shit up!!!” type of posts. He even has a couple posts about wrecking his truck drunk driving. He got kicked out of his fraternity when he got arrested, couldn’t pass classes, switched his major several times, dropped out, moved back to the farm, then went to community college and got his AA just so he could say he finished something. He had at least 84k in private student loans, but paid off 30k in 5 or so years, now at 54k. He has lived with his family since he came back from university in 2011. He makes 54k as an apprentice ironworker (he is one year in) and should make $36/hr in two years. However he did waver getting into iron, and he has considered another job offer recently at his old mechanic job, so he does not seem that committed or happy as the work is very tough and commute can be long, and also he smokes weed he says only on special occasions although he gets randomly drug tested at work, which I believe could cost him his job. I think he said he had $54k in retirement as I thought he said he broke even with his debt. He currently pays $1.2k on his student loans monthly, he told me recently. I knew he had student debt but he just told me how much recently.
He still sleeps on his old futon from college in his dad’s unfinished basement. Their home is neglected and not clean. Unfinished projects and cracked walls and cabinet doors missing and expired food. His mom is really mentally ill and recently divorced the dad a few months ago. No one in the family likes her and they idolize their dad who is a very sweet man and good man but also makes questionable decisions, and also there’s a lot of beer cans around and I’m not sure who’s all drinking the beer, maybe he drinks a lot I’m not sure, I think all of them do (boyfriend, lil brother, and dad). I know my boyfriend’s brother said about my boyfriend, “when are you not drinking?” And boyfriend looked to me nervously and quickly to see my reaction. He told me before he doesn’t drink much though. He doesn’t at my house, he usually comes over and spends the night on Saturdays and stay until Sunday evening.
We planned to move in together in a couple of months, my mom encouraged me to ask him, with me moving out to him possibly renting an apartment (my choice) or house (he would like 2-3 bedrooms and a garage he said at first, but then said later after looking he could do an apartment) he lives an hour away in the country. Although there is really like no places for rent out there. He said he could do up to 30 minutes south of him which is in the middle of us but wants to be 10-15 minutes from the farm. He could transfer to the union in my city with the best jobs but doesn’t want to. His friends live north of him which I suspect may be a reason, he knew two guys in iron in the union

<post>
Title: tell me what you find when you read my mind

Body:
I feel a bit ridiculous but here goes. When I ask my romantic partners to do something that would make me feel cared for, the act of me asking for it negates any special feelings from them doing it. It then doesn't feel like they're doing it because they care, they're doing it because I asked them to. But they're obviously doing it because they care and want me to be happy. How do I solve this in my brain? (examples inside)
Examples.
. I ask them about their day/how they're going/what do they have on today/so on. They rarely do the same, even if I give them positive feedback after they do it. After a clearer conversation, they put a reminder in their phone to ask me what I'm up to every day. It doesn't feel good when they ask because it doesn't feel like they genuinely care, they just ask because I wanted them to
. I express that I'm hurt that partner isn't curious about me and doesn't know basic facts about me, they apologize and ask me the questions I raised as examples. It feels like the important part to me is their taking the initiative and without that the gesture feels empty.
. I hint that I always did X-activity with past partners and that it's special to me in relationships specifically when I'm asked to do this with them (rather than the other way round). Partner took a while to come around to it and took a bit of convincing because in their previous relationship, that was a friend-only activity and their partner was hostile to it. When they finally started doing it with me, even though they asked me to do it often, it didn't ever feel great doing it because it felt like, despite reassurances, that they're asking me as part of being a Good Partner rather than because they enjoy it with me.
So on. It feels petty and I hate feeling this way when my partners are making an effort but I have a hard time not feeling sad over it.

Title: Don’t know how to feel about partner’s small lies and where to go next

Body:
My partner and I have been dating for 5 years, but I recently found out he told a lie about the content of a racy social media channel he follows and donates to, and also about his porn usage. I emphasized that honesty was very important in the beginning of our relationship, and now I don’t know where to go next, and how big of a deal this is in relationships.
My partner (M, 40s) and I have been together for around 5 years. In the early days of dating, I emphasized to him that honesty is very important to me, and we also talked about various viewpoints and boundaries. One of the topics that came up was around porn usage. I tried to approach it from a flexible and positive stance (learned from previous relationships about communicating in a more open way around sensitive topics, and tried extra hard to apply that here), that I understood most people watch porn and there’s varying views around it, that my personal preference/boundaries was to not have porn usage in a relationship, and wanted to know what his views were. He had watched porn quite a lot throughout his life, but he said it was fine with him and agreed/promised he would no longer watch it. I said if something ever comes up in the future and he feels like it’s an issue, to please tell me and we can talk about it and maybe we can adjust instead of hiding it etc.
Things were mostly fine for a few years but recently there was an incident where I realized he had lied/omitted the truth. There’s this social media channel he’s always followed. They’re borderline explicit, but mostly a comedy channel. Though their content is mostly sexual humor (since their popularity with their users and income is mostly from the sexual stuff around the female cast), just borderline enough to not get banned. It bothered me a bit in the beginning but my partner said he just watches it because it’s funny, so I didn’t mind too much. In one of the reddit threads about how much the comedy channel makes, there were a ton of comments that were just dudes asking for more explicit content from the female cast, saying they would pay even more for it etc. (the main discussion was also someone curious how much the channel makes, and then went into how the sexual content boosts their earnings). I remembered my partner said he is a tiered subscriber and actually pays money each month, but he had said it was just that he wanted to support creators that he likes. I felt a little uneasy about the reddit comments, so I asked him if there was any inappropriate content for paid subscribers (since the thread mentioned paid ones get special access to certain videos). He said no it’s just bloopers and funny things like that and brushed it off. But the way he said it sounded weird. So I ended up looking up online (pretty easy to find) what the special videos were, and turns out it was actually more explicit stuff like the women play games and strip down to their underwear, or things related to sex toys etc. I confronted him, and he admitted he did lie. We had a big argument and I told him if he was lying about anything else it would eventually come out, and whether he had been watching porn. He then finally admitted that yes he had also been watching porn (but he said only a few times a year for stress relief).
Afterwards, he did seem very remorseful, and tried to proactively repair things, but I’m finding it hard to see him and the relationship the same way again. He did say he has issues with communication and talking about things, which I can see from the times I met his family - they pretty much don’t even ask or communicate about normal things like “so how many times do you want to come for dinner when you’re visiting our city” etc and everyone just makes weird assumptions and then gets resentful. He always had a lot of trouble talking about sex and more recently mentioned there was some shame around masturbation etc growing up. <post>
Title: Is there a way to point out that friend is grossly self centered?

Body:
Below is a long ass thing about another married couple friend of ours, but it boils down to this: if your friend never/rarely asks about you, what can be done?
Husband and I have been friends with another couple, let's call them Roger and Sandy, for about 10 years. I feel like the relationship was more balanced, but the last few years have become very one-sided. Husband thinks it's always been one-sided. I am thinking we are both right, but I am guessing I used to assert myself into the conversation. I am growing so tired of this unbalanced friendship. In all fairness, when I/we do push and share they sincerely do care but I am flabbergasted that they never would have asked. And this is proven, if we don't shove our way into the conversation and assert ourselves they will not inquire. Naturally we don't hang out with them nearly as much as we used to, maybe every other month and that feels like a lot.
I've been thinking about this more because I have a trip coming up with Sandy. Our kids are very very good friends and for a long time the kids (age 16) have wanted to do a special trip. Normally this would be something I would be excited for but now I am wondering how should I prepare? I don't want some friendship showdown on this trip and I also even wonder if people can change-so MeFi, what do you say? I hate confrontation but if you say it's time for a pow wow then fine. If you say it's time for slow fade, fine. Time for polite-neutral-whatever time, fine. In the times immediately afterwards our get-togethers I think there must be something I can say, not too rude-but a little pointed that might make them realize how beastly they are? When we go out Husband and I play off of each other and give prompts like we are in some terrible skit. It's just ridiculous.
On review, I am looking for advice of kind MeFis who have had similar experience and how I can gage my expectations on this. I swear I used to feel close to these guys and now I just don't even know what to do with them. They don't feel like friends at all.
I have other things I want to talk about but I worry it would cloud the replies and everyone will be like DTMFs but I want to keep it at this core issue because I have experienced it with other friends and it leaves me completely stumped. I seem to notice it more post Covid, but it could be me that's changed.
